headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe picks who will decide whether or not Erik ten Hag will stay at Man Utd
body: Erik ten Hag's long-term future at Manchester United will be determined in the summer - but whether or not he stays at Old Trafford will not be decided by Sir Jim Ratcliffe
Manchester United's incoming chief executive Omar Berrada will ultimately be the person who decides whether or not Erik ten Hag will remain in his post next season, it has emerged.

Berrada has a wealth of expertise after filling the role of chief football operating officer at Manchester City and is poised to head up football operations at Old Trafford once he officially starts his new role in the summer following a period of gardening leave.

Plundering Berrada from City was Sir Jim Ratcliffe's first major coup since acquiring a 27.7 per cent stake in his boyhood club from the Glazers, but the Ineos chief is likely to make further moves in an attempt to enhance United's operations. Dan Ashworth is expected to join the club as sporting director once an agreement for his services is reached with Newcastle, but there is still no clarity over the future of the man currently leading United on the pitch.

Despite impressing during his maiden season, Ten Hag has overseen an underwhelming 2023/24 campaign. His fate will be decided by Berrada, though, rather than Ratcliffe himself, according to the Manchester Evening News.

It's outlined that Ratcliffe is happy to delegate the decision-making process over Ten Hag's future to Berrada given his 'football expertise'. It's also noted that the Dutchman is now likely to see the season out after reaching the semi-final of the FA Cup.
Ten Hag signed a three-year contract with the Red Devils in the summer of 2022 after leaving Ajax, meaning he is contracted to continue in his role for the 2024/25 campaign.
However, speculation over his long-term future has only intensified since the arrival of Ratcliffe and co, with the British billionaire failing to publicly endorse United's current chief.

Despite an underwhelming season, Ten Hag insisted United are still on course for a bright future and pointed to injuries as a mitigating factor behind their poor form. Speaking at the start of the month, he said: "No team can deal with this, with so many injuries. I think we are playing to maximum levels if you take in the availability of the players.
"So, when you miss so many key players over many parts of the season, then obviously the results, the performances will not be (the same as) when the players are available.

"We have seen when the players were available like in January and February our performances were very good. And I think from that moment when the players were not even fit, they could have done even better when they are 100 per cent fit in that moment but they were not."

headline: Arsenal icon Bob Wilson details Sir Alex Ferguson gesture after deaths of wife and daughter
body: Bob Wilson is an Arsenal legend who will forever remember the gestures made by Manchester United icon Sir Alex Ferguson after the deaths of his daughter and his wife
The moments where Sir Alex Ferguson showcased his class still remain with Arsenal great Bob Wilson as he dealt with personal grief.

The legendary goalkeeper made more than 300 appearances for the Gunners, later becoming a coach with the north Londoners - a role he would hold for 28 years before calling it a day in 2003. During that latter part of that lengthy spell Arsenal had become embroiled in a fierce rivalry with Manchester United.

Arsenal were the only club to challenge United's authority and, as a results, Ferguson and Arsene Wenger had their moments - as did the players on the pitch. Nevertheless, Ferguson knew where to leave the rivalry and his human side left its mark on Wilson after the passing of his wife, Megs, whom he'd been with for 70 years.
The Gunners dedicated a page to Wilson's wife in a matchday programme with Ferguson among those present at her recent Memorial Service at a full St Albans Cathedral.

Wilson told the Telegraph: “It showed Arsenal’s class. Alex [Ferguson] drove four hours, came to the service, went back. I made sure Frank McLintock and George Graham were right by him. I got a message two days after from a close friend who said, ‘There were these three Scottish blokes in the row behind me and I gather one of them is very famous. Well, my husband and I could not understand one word they said!’”

Ferguson had also taken the time out to phone Wilson back in 1998 when their daughter, Anna, died of cancer at the tragic age of 31. That was during United's treble winning season, in which Arsenal were their main rivals in the Premier League and the FA Cup.

Wilson recalled: “Three nights after Anna died, the phone rang. ‘Hiya Bob, it’s Alex’. I was, ‘Alex??’ He was, ‘Yeah, Alex Ferguson ’. He spoke to me, said, ‘You sound as if you are holding up but where’s Megs?’ He then spoke to her for 20 minutes. I’ll never forget that.”

Anna's death led to the beginning of their Willow Foundation charity, for which Megs was the driving force. So much so that Wilson initially tuned down his OBE in 2007 because it had not gone to his wife. “I said, ‘You deserve this more’. She went berserk. She said, ‘It’s not just for Willow, it’s what you have done in football’.”

headline: Great disruptors Liverpool could dictate WSL title race after Man Utd and Arsenal warnings
body: Liverpool Women leapfrogged Manchester United in the Women's Super League table and could influence the outcome of a blistering title race
Going back to the beginning, Liverpool Women have given plenty of forewarning.

Midfielder Miri Taylor consigned juggernauts Arsenal to an opening day defeat in the Women’s Super League with a second-half strike and the significance was profound. Not so much a statement as much as an announcement: Liverpool are here.

Talk of upsetting an entrenched top four have been fevered in the last few seasons but few have managed to gatecrash the established elite as effectively as Liverpool this season. In only their second season in England's top-flight since promotion from the Championship, Liverpool – fuelled by savvy recruitment and Matt Beard’s management – sit fourth in the league, one point above Manchester United and eight points off third-place Arsenal.
Liverpool have defeated United and Arsenal this season and could ultimately dictate the title race if league leaders Chelsea and Manchester City – separated by two goals – aren’t careful.
Indeed, both Chelsea and City are due to face Liverpool before the season’s expiry at Prenton Park as a blistering title race continues.

Following Manchester City's thrashing of Manchester United on Saturday, Gareth Taylor insisted that the title race could go down to the wire with just five games remaining. Yet, one of the most epic title races in recent memory could be decided before if Liverpool have anything to say about it. Last season, Liverpool revelled in victories over Chelsea and City in front of a spirited Prenton Park, both teams stymied by a stubborn and unwavering home defence.

Doing so again will doubtlessly prove a challenge. Liverpool suffered 5-1 defeats to both City and Chelsea in the league this season, succumbing to an onslaught of pressure after early goals and failing to match the energy from their opponents. The campaign’s final throes is where Chelsea, and City, tend to come to searing into life.

Yet, Beard has never shied away from his mission of breaking up the established order and as praise was heaped on his side for getting within touching distance of the top four as Aston Villa and Tottenham Hotspur had done previously, the Liverpool boss steadfastly insisted that reaching that space was only the beginning.

Liverpool had a golden opportunity on Sunday to bridge the gap to Arsenal in third and expand that between themselves and United. But a drab draw with Everton away at Goodison Park and a lack of quality in the final third meant the Reds have five matches remaining to yield their influence on the fate of the league, including a home clash against United to further stamp their authority.

It’s here the margins still remain. Beard bemoaned the “disappointing” quality of Everton’s Premier League pitch, pointing to the long grass and the Toffees’ commitment to stoking a stuttering tempo as playing a role in the lethargic display.

Whether the perceived marginal injustices will fuel Liverpool come Saturday as they host City remains to be seen. City are in siege mode, 10 WSL victories on the bounce and Khadija Shaw setting a new club record for goals scored. But Liverpool are bidding to be the season’s disruptor and thus far, have cut themselves the convincing figure.

headline: What happened to Man Utd prospect Adnan Januzaj after relegation and winner vs England
body: England are aiming to avoid a fourth defeat in five meetings with Belgium in Tuesday's friendly at Wembley, with Adnan Januzaj heavily involved in one of those recent games
England's recent record against Belgium isn't the best, and the Three Lions have often found themselves put to the sword by Premier League players.

Three of the last four meetings between the national teams have gone the way of the Belgians, with Youri Tielemans netting in a 2020 Nations League clash and Eden Hazard on target in the third-place play-off at the 2018 World Cup. Earlier at the tournament in Russia, though, it was Adnan Januzaj who took centre-stage.

Januzaj, 23 at the time, was one year removed from his Manchester United exit when he cut in from the right and curled the ball high into Jordan Pickford's net. The goal ensured Belgium topped their group ahead of England, with both teams going on to reach the semi-finals.

After a disappointing end to his time at Old Trafford, the winger will have wanted to kick on from that World Cup success, but has added just six more Belgium appearances since. Here, Mirror Football looks at what the Brussels-born star has been up to.

After breaking into the United team under David Moyes, Januzaj found chances harder to come by during the reigns of Louis van Gaal and Jose Mourinho. He spent part of the 2015-16 season on loan at Borussia Dortmund, struggling to get a look in under Thomas Tuchel, before a reunion with Moyes for the following campaign.

A difficult season at the Stadium of Light saw Moyes' Sunderland team relegated, with Januzaj failing to score in his 25 appearances. A permanent move to Real Sociedad followed, though, and his form in San Sebastian was what earned him a spot in Roberto Martinez's World Cup squad.

The England game was the only one in which he featured, remaining on the bench for the remainder of the tournament. He didn't even make it onto the field in the third place game, when goals from Thomas Meunier and Eden Hazard earned the Red Devils the bronze medal.

Januzaj had been brought to Real Sociedad by Eusebio Sacristan, but it was under current boss Imanol Alguacil where he really thrived. The 2019-20 season was his best in front of goal, with eight strikes in all competitions, and none were more important than the final day equaliser at Atletico Madrid which sent La Real into Europe.

"Januzaj, the day of the Sevilla match, was really injured and had not trained, but he wanted to be called up [against Atletico], and I said no," Alguacil said, as translated by Marca. "You know that, with me, whoever doesn't train does not play.

"So he then told me that he would not travel to Madrid, and I laughed and joked to [assistant coach] Labaka: 'Look at this guy, he says he is not going to travel to Madrid, and he will, and he will end up taking us to Europe.' In the end he travelled, played injured and scored the goal that got us into Europe."

That Europa League campaign brought a reunion with former club Manchester United. Alguacil's side finished second in their group behind Napoli, setting up a play-off round meeting with United after Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's team could only muster third spot in their Champions League group.

Before the game, former United player and coach Paul Scholes acknowledged Januzaj needed to leave Old Trafford to kick-start his career. “The talent no doubt was there. It’s still there, he’s doing really well at Sociedad. I think it’s been a good change for him," he told MUTV.
"He showed glimpses when he first came into United’s first team, that he had the ability that we all knew he had. For some reason it just didn’t work out and he’s had to go elsewhere."

Sadly for Real Sociedad, that meeting ended in a comprehensive 4-0 aggregate loss, with United going all the way to the final. Another exit followed at the same stage 12 months later, with RB Leipzig progressing after a win at Anoeta, but an appearance from the bench in that game would represent the last time Januzaj turned out for La Real in European competition.

His contract expired at the end of the 2021-22 season, paving the way for him to join Sevilla in a four-year deal. He barely featured under Julen Lopetegui or Jorge Sampaoli, though, and ended the campaign on loan at Istanbul Basaksehir in search of minutes.
Januzaj's international career has also suffered. The goal against England remains the only one he has scored for his country, and hasn't even earned a call-up since the summer of 2022.

This season has been a tricky one for Sevilla, who are onto their third permanent manager of the season. Januzaj made a late cameo from the bench in current boss Quique Sanchez Flores' first game in charge, but has yet to start in the league since returning from his loan.

“The boys are professionals and each one understands the degree of demand in a different way, but I have to place that demand at a higher level for him and Rafa Mir," Sanchez Flores said in February. "After having gone to them in the times of absolute necessity, there is no time to lower the bar now.

"Anyone who does not meet that requirement either reaches it, or cannot play. Now things change, it is not enough to be a good professional but you have to have the necessary commitment to defend the Sevilla shirt.”

Januzaj is under contract until 2026, but has played just one minute since those comments from the manager and may well feel his future lies elsewhere. That winner against England feels a long time ago.

headline: Man Utd news: Kobbie Mainoo praised as Erik ten Hag target issues future update
body: Manchester United's teenage sensation Kobbie Mainoo made his England debut on Saturday night at just 18 years of age against the mighty Brazil at a packed Wembley Stadium
A number of Manchester United stars have been representing their national teams in the last few days and Erik ten Hag will be desperate to see them all return fully fit.

Morale is still sky high around Old Trafford after the final game before the international break saw the Red Devils dump rivals Liverpool out of the FA Cup with a last-gasp winner in extra time to triumph 4-3. As a result, a semi-final clash with Championship side Coventry City at Wembley awaits Ten Hag's side.

While the FA Cup is United's last chance of silverware this term, there is still hope of Champions League qualification as well. The 13-time Premier League winners currently sit sixth in the table, but it looks increasingly likely that fifth-place will be enough to seal a place in European club football's most prestigious competition.
The Red Devils are six points adrift of Tottenham who are one place above them in fifth. Mirror Football has taken a look at the main headlines emerging out of Old Trafford.

United's teen sensation Kobbie Mainoo earned his first England cap at senior level on Saturday night, coming off the bench to feature against Brazil. It marked the next step in a sensational rise for the 18-year-old, who only made his full Premier League debut in November.

After the game, Mainoo was the subject of praise from a number of his colleagues for club and country. The teenager took to Instagram to write: "Special feeling making my senior England debut at Wembley and in front of my family. A moment I will never forget. Now we bounce back and refocus for Tuesday."

The comment section was littered with compliments, with Rice writing: "Many more to come! Congrats bro." United skipper Bruno Fernandes added: "First of many," while Harry Maguire contributed: "Deserved mate."

Rasmus Hojlund was notably frustrated throughout Denmark's 0-0 draw against Switzerland on Saturday night.

Danish publication BT reported that the young striker looked 'ready to boil over' after not being found on the pitch by some of his team-mates, including Hojlund's United colleague Christian Eriksen. The Red Devils forward was withdrawn seven minutes before the full-time whistle.
Barcelona defender Ronald Araujo insists he has no desire to leave Camp Nou amid rumours that United are keen on the Uruguay international.
"There’s been a lot of talk about this issue, but I’m happy in Barcelona," Araujo said, as translated by Football Espana.
"In addition, we have to finish the season well because there are still challenges, also with Uruguay with the Copa America."
Araujo was heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford while Raphael Varane was sidelined with an injury. The ex-Real Madrid ace has since played his way back into the fold under Ten Hag.

headline: Man Utd bring in stadium designers as chiefs ponder 100,000-capacity 'new Old Trafford'
body: Manchester United co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe wants to revamp the club's stadium and designers have reportedly drawn up plans already which are now being examined
The designers responsible for Tottenham's new stadium have drawn up plans for Manchester United as new co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe considers the future of Old Trafford.

Ratcliffe wants United to have a start-of-the-art stadium and will need to either renovate Old Trafford or build an entirely new ground. Speaking on the Geraint Thomas Cycling Club podcast earlier this month, the Ineos chief hinted at plans to increase capacity to 100,000.

"You have got this opportunity if you choose to, to build a completely new ground, because we have got enough space," Ratcliffe said. "If you built a completely new ground it would absolutely be state-of-the-art, world class, 90,000 or maybe even 100,000 that then provides a platform for some of the big competitions in the north of England.
"Why do England always play in the south? Why is the FA Cup final always in the south? Why can't the Champions League final be in the north occasionally?
"Football in the north is just as important as it is in the south, arguably more so, and the people in the north pay their taxes, so why do we have Wembley, Twickenham, Wimbledon etc in the south.

"What have we got in the north? There's a strong argument to build a 'Wembley of the north'." And according to a report from the Daily Mail, stadium designers Populous have already come up with proposals to renovate or rebuild Old Trafford.

Populous are said to have been brought in by the Glazers and that the plans they came up with are now being 'scrutinised by Ratcliffe's INEOS people'. A task force was set up earlier this month to explore the club's options, with former United captain Gary Neville, Lord Sebastian Coe and the Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham all involved.

And Neville has admitted the "commercial aspect" will ultimately be the deciding factor for Ratcliffe. "I think everyone knows that it's one of two options; either renovate and refurbish the existing Old Trafford or develop a brand new stadium next to Old Trafford," he told Sky Sports.

"Every structural solution is different. Until you get into the meat of the work and see what is really brought forward then I don't think anyone has the answer. That's the reason that the group has been set up, to help answer some of those questions.

"The work that goes on and the findings of the work that goes down [will help form a decision], but it will also come down to the commercial aspect of what will be afforded. We know that a new stadium – well, a refurbishment costs a lot of money – but a brand new stadium costs more."

headline: Man Utd outcast set for Old Trafford return as decision made on future
body: After struggling for game time at Manchester United, Donny van de Beek joined Eintracht Frankfurt on loan in January but the move has not gone to plan so far
Donny van de Beek looks set to return to Manchester United at the end of the season following his loan spell at Eintracht Frankfurt.
United forked out £40million to sign Van de Beek from Ajax in 2020 after he starred for the Dutch giants as they reached the semi-finals of the Champions League the previous year.

However, he has failed to make an impact at Old Trafford and is now in his second loan spell away from the club. Having made just four starts for United in the last two years, Van de Beek joined Frankfurt on loan in January in a bid to get some game time and rediscover his form.

The deal also included an option to buy, but Bild are now reporting that Frankfurt have no plans to make the move permanent. The 26-year-old has made six appearances for the Bundesliga side and was left out of their Europa Conference League squad last month

"He's only played a total of four games in the last two years, so it won't happen overnight," head coach Dino Toppmoller said of the decision. "But I have 100 per cent confidence in his quality, he'll definitely help us in the second half of the season.

"I told Donny that I was sorry but also what I expected from him now." Van de Beek also suffered the ignominy of being taken off in a game against Bochum where he had come on as a substitute in the first place.
"Unfortunately, I had to replace Donny again," Toppmoller explained after the game. "This is because we knew he wouldn't be able to keep up the power for 70 minutes."

Speaking before his move to Frankfurt last November, Van de Beek admitted he was desperate to play regular football again. ''I am bouncing to play matches again. The manager is making different choices now," he said.

"We have a big squad and I am not the only one knocking on the door. We'll see in January what happens. I need to start playing games very soon - if not at Man United then at another club. I think I have to be ambitious.
"I have always been a lover of the game. I am absolutely crazy about football. I earn a good living at United, but money is not my motivation. I want to enjoy my work every day."

headline: Man Utd 'could be barred' from Europe next season due to Sir Jim Ratcliffe takeover
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe has insisted his ownership of French side Nice will not cause any problems for Manchester United, despite UEFA's rules on multi-club ownership
Manchester United could be banned from playing in Europe next season following Sir Jim Ratcliffe's purchase of a minority stake in the club, according to reports.
Ratcliffe also owns French side OGC Nice, who currently sit fifth in Ligue 1, and UEFA's rules on multi-club ownership mean they would not be allowed to compete in the same competition.

UEFA have changed their rules slightly, allowing clubs under common ownership to compete in different European competitions as of next season, but the ban on those teams playing in the same tournament remains.

"It is correct that Manchester United and Nice cannot play in the same competition," a UEFA insider is quoted as telling the Sun. "They could play in different competitions, as there is no 'feeding' between competitions any more."
If both United and Nice do end up qualifying for the same competition then UEFA rules state that the club which "ranked highest in the domestic championship" will take precedence.

However, Ratcliffe insisted back in February that the rules will not impact United's ability to play in Europe. "There are no circumstances upon which an ownership of Nice would prevent Manchester United from playing in the Champions League - I'll be crystal clear on that," he said.

"Because we would have to find a solution. The rules are changing, and the rules are shades of grey, not black and white. We have spoken to UEFA and I have to say the conversation wasn't directed at 'you have to solve this problem and we don't like it'.

"We might have to change some things but what UEFA recognises is that the multi-club model, in many circumstances, benefits the smaller club quite a lot. It says you have to change the ownership structure.

"So it's all about influence and positions on the board and that sort of thing. So, a) the rules are changing, and, b) there are shades of grey, not black and white. Manchester City will probably have the problem before we have the problem because they've obviously got Girona who are doing well in the Spanish La Liga."

headline: Antony reveals Man Utd teammate who's been 'more than a friend' during difficult period
body: Antony has endured a difficult couple of seasons since arriving for big money from Dutch side Ajax but has been given friendly support by one of his teammates at Old Trafford
Antony has praised Diogo Dalot for helping him overcome a tricky period at Manchester United.
The Brazilian winger has endured a difficult couple of seasons since arriving at Old Trafford for £86m from Ajax. He scored just eight goals during his debut campaign.
Things have got even worse for Antony since then. He has fallen down the pecking order under Erik ten Hag, scoring just twice this season.

It has also been claimed that the Red Devils would be willing to cut their losses on the 24-year-old. But Antony still has support in the dressing room and has picked out Portuguese defender Dalot for his support during his time at Old Trafford.

Speaking to United’s official website, the Brazilian said: “I'm very grateful to God and to a friend I talk to a lot. Diogo Dalot is more than a friend to me, he's a guy who helps me every day at the club.

“We have a phrase that we always say to each other: the patient guy is unbeatable. We always talk about it. So I'm very grateful to him for his advice, for the moments we had together talking. He's a guy who's helped me a lot.”

Dalot has spoken out on his friendship with Antony in the past. Explaining a handshake that the pair shared after the Brazilian had set up the defender for a goal vs Nottingham Forest last season, he said: "It’s our thing. I’m happy I have a good relationship with him, he’s a fantastic kid, I like to be around him."

Antony found the net during his most recent outing - the dramatic 4-3 win against Liverpool in the FA Cup. Erik ten Hag claimed that he was approaching the player he originally signed after that performance.

The Dutchman said: “It's very important for him. He struggled so much. First part, he was not himself, he's responsible for that. And then he lost confidence, and now he has to fight back. We see through the last two weeks, he's returning.
“I see in training, I see the Antony I was used to work with at Ajax, and also used to work in the first weeks here. He has to fight back, and I'm sure he will do, because you've seen that goal.

“But not only in the goal. When he's going to left full-back position, he's defending very well. In certain systems, he can play from that side. He's not a defending player, don't get me wrong, because we have seen, he can score goals.”

headline: Man Utd star Marcus Rashford in line to match unwanted England record against Belgium
body: Manchester United star Marcus Rashford has earned 60 caps for England, 34 of which have come as a substitute, and he is now on the verge of equalling Jermain Defoe's record for the most appearances off the bench
Marcus Rashford is set to match an England record if he comes off the bench in their upcoming friendly against Belgium on Tuesday.

Rashford made a 15-minute cameo in England's 1-0 defeat to Brazil on Saturday after replacing debutant Anthony Gordon - the 34th time the Manchester United star has represented his country as a substitute.
Former West Ham and Tottenham Hotspur striker Jermain Defoe currently holds the record for the most substitute appearances for England with 35 and Rashford is now on the brink of matching that.

England boss Gareth Southgate is expected to ring the changes against Belgium, having had a host of players pull out of the squad with injuries. Arsenal's Bukayo Saka went home with a minor injury last week, while captain Harry Kane returned to Bayern Munich after the Brazil game to continue his recovery from an ankle injury.

Kyle Walker has been replaced in the squad by his Manchester City teammate Rico Lewis after suffering a hamstring injury, while Crystal Palace goalkeeper Sam Johnstone has picked up an elbow issue and been replaced by Burnley's James Trafford.

Harry Maguire has also been sent home after limping off against Brazil. Chelsea star Cole Palmer and Ajax midfielder Jordan Henderson both missed the Brazil game with knocks, but Southgate expects them both to be fit to face Belgium.

"We have a long list of 40-odd players and a third are unavailable which is the highest we have ever had," Southgate said when asked about the injury crisis. "I think no Kane for Saturday, no Henderson, no Cole Palmer.

"Bukayo arrived with a hamstring problem and didn't train so he has gone back. Everybody across the League has a high number of injuries but it is always more complex. Everyone wants a simple solution to complex problems.

"Some players have been unfortunate. Kane's injury was when he crashed into the net at the weekend and it forced a mechanism with his ankle. He had a winter break and is not playing in our league. Some players have played too many games and there's been a raft of injuries with the intensity of the games."

headline: Harry Maguire hands Man Utd fresh injury scare as defender leaves England camp
body: Harry Maguire has joined Kyle Walker and Sam Johnstone in pulling out of the England squad as James Trafford and Rico Lewis are called up from the Under-21s
Gareth Southgate has been dealt fresh injury blows to throw his plans for Tuesday’s friendly with Belgium into chaos.
Kyle Walker and Harry Maguire have both gone back to their clubs after having scans after England’s defeat to Brazil on Saturday.
Manchester City defender Walker limped off after just 20 minutes after fears he might have tweaked a hamstring which is a massive worry ahead of their title run-in.
Manchester United defender Maguire has just returned from injury and was substituted and will also miss the friendly with Belgium on Tuesday.
City youngster Rico Lewis has been promoted from the under-21s to the senior squad having made his England debut in North Macedonia last November.
Keeper Sam Johnstone is also being replaced by Burnley’s James Trafford after the Crystal Palace stopper suffered an elbow problem.
England captain Harry Kane returned to Bayern Munich after the Brazil game as he suffered an ankle issue.
Jude Bellingham also suffered cramp during the Brazil game while Arsenal’s Bukayo Saka went home last week but is expected to be fit to face Manchester City next Sunday.
It is yet another blow for Southgate’s plans as he had hoped to use the back-to-back friendlies with Brazil and Belgium as Euro auditions as a trial run for his strongest line-up ahead of the summer.
But Southgate has now seen key members of his squad return to their clubs even before the second game on Tuesday.
That means he will be forced into changes against Belgium with club managers also anxious their top stars are not risked and avoid injury.
Cole Palmer and Jordan Henderson are expected to be available for Belgium, having missed Brazil with knocks.

United will be keeping their fingers crossed that Maguire is not ruled out for the foreseeable future. He has made 24 appearances for the Red Devils so far this term. Maguire would join fellow defenders Luke Shaw on the sidelines, while Lisandro Martinez is also still working his way back to full fitness.
Maguire’s exit leaves Southgate’s options even more limited. Dunk, Joe Gomez, Jarred Branthwaite, John Stones and Ezri Konsa are among England’s centre-back options.

The latter made his England debut against Brazil but was required to deputise at right-back after Walker was withdrawn with his own injury. Speaking after the game about the Man City star’s fitness, Southgate said: “We don’t know yet, he’s feeling something.
“He's not a player who’s been injured very often so he’s not quite certain what it is. So we just have to assess it over the next couple of days.”

Walker has since broken his silence in his issue. Taking to Instagram, he said: "Frustrating to come off injured in last night's game especially when captaining the side. A truly great honour. Hopefully it’s nothing too serious and I’m back ASAP."

headline: Jose Mourinho details managerial return plan two months after being sacked by Roma
body: Former Chelsea, Man United and Tottenham boss Jose Mourinho has been out of work since leaving Roma in January but is now eyeing a return to football over the next few months
Jose Mourinho is targeting a return to management this summer, just months after his Roma sacking.

The Portuguese head coach left the Italian capital in January after two-and-a-half years at the helm. He had led Roma to the Europa Conference League title during his debut campaign, as well as a place in the Europa League final the following season.

Since then, Mourinho has been linked with a host of roles. A potential move to Saudi Arabia has been reported, while Newcastle and even his former club Chelsea have been touted as potential employers.

While Mourinho has not disclosed a preference for his return, he has claimed he wants to be back in the dugout ahead of next season. Asked at the Moto GP in Portimao, Portugal, if he had received any offers, he replied: “Zero, zero. I don’t have a club, I’m free. But I want to work, in the summer I want to work.”
One option for Mourinho could be a return to Portugal. The 61-year-old has not managed in his home country since ending his glorious spell with Porto ahead of a move to Chelsea in 2004.
Asked if he could work in Portugal, Mourinho said: “Why? Never say no, especially in football. My life is football, I can train anywhere, I have no problems.”

Mourinho’s admission comes just days after Ex-Roma General Manager Tiago Pinto opened up on the decision to sack him. He claimed that the Portuguese’s exit was his toughest call at the Stadio Olimpico.
Where do you think Jose Mourinho will turn up next? Share your predictions in the comments below

Speaking to Sky Sports, Pinto said: “Mourinho’s dismissal? That was a very difficult day for everyone. I’m still young, I don’t know if older sports directors manage such situations differently. I die the moment a coach has to be fired. The emotions are too high, it was a collaboration of two and a half years coming to an end.”

Elsewhere, Mourinho appeared to take aim at the Roma hierarchy for the decision to sack him. Talking to Rio Ferdinand two months after his exit, he said: “I’ll be back. I won’t be there for the final stages of the season, not because I’ve been eliminated before, but because I’ve been “eliminated” by someone who has little knowledge of football.”
Roma’s decision to change manager actually looked like being the correct one. They replaced him with iconic former midfielder Daniele De Rossi.

The Italian has won nine out of his 13 matches in all competitions. Roma now sit fifth in Serie A and just three points off of the Champions League places. The club were ninth in the league at the time of Mourinho’s sacking.

headline: Man Utd's Rasmus Hojlund "ready to boil over" as furious reaction to team-mates spotted
body: Rasmus Hojlund has been all smiles at Manchester United recently, but was far from happy with some of his Denmark team-mates during their recent 0-0 draw against Switzerland
Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund was notably frustrated throughout Denmark's 0-0 draw against Switzerland on Saturday night.

The two nations met for a friendly fixture, but Hojlund was reported to have looked like he was 'ready to boil over' by Danish publication BT. The young forward has recently just started to find form in a United shirt after a difficult start to life at Old Trafford following his mega-money move from Serie A side Atalanta in the summer.

Hojlund went his first 14 Premier League games without a goal, before at long last finding the net during the Boxing Day win over Aston Villa. Since then, the Denmark international has barely looked back for his club, boasting seven goals and two assists in the league overall.

With that being said, he struggled to maintain that same form for his national side during this international break. Hojlund didn't even last the full 90 minutes and was withdrawn seven minutes before the full-time whistle, but not before he made his anger clear on the pitch.

Having taken up a number of promising positions throughout the game only to be ignored by his team-mates, the striker is believed to have screamed in fury multiple times. Hojlund wasn't the only United representative on the pitch, with Red Devils midfielder Christian Eriksen also starring for the entire fixture.

Eriksen hasn't had the luxury of featuring for United as much as he'd like recently. Hojlund actually went public with his desire to see his fellow countryman get more time on the pitch at Old Trafford.
"I myself have sat on the bench for Copenhagen, so I know what that means," Hojlund told TV2. "But he holds his head high and he is a class player. There is absolutely no doubt about that.

"There is no concern at all from me about it. Of course, you want to play football. And I’m sure he does too. [But] he trains well and is still very positive and very helpful, so it’s not a big deal. He is a real professional.

"It was good he got some minutes against Liverpool. I think he did really well when he came on. He is a good player, so you would like to see him on the field, but we have many good players. So it must be the coach’s decision whether he plays or not."

headline: Barcelona star warned off Man Utd transfer by Rio Ferdinand makes statement on future
body: Manchester United are expected to dip back into the transfer market over the summer and one man continually linked with an Old Trafford switch has made clear his stance
Barcelona defender Ronald Araujo insists he has no desire to leave Camp Nou, having been linked repeatedly with a Manchester United switch in recent transfer windows.

Back in December, former United defender Rio Ferdinand suggested if he was in Araujo''s position then he'd shun an Old Trafford switch for fear such a move could risk his career. At the time, former La Liga star Raphael Varane had lost his starting spot, though the Frenchman has since found his way back in thanks to colleagues' injuries, and Ferdinand made comparisons between the two.

United are preparing for a busy summer after the investment from Sir Jim Ratcliffe, and centre-back could be a key area, especially if they're unable to agree new terms with Varane. The France defender is out of contract in the summer, with the Premier League club opting against triggering an extension on his current wages.

Uruguay international Araujo in no mind to leave Catalunya for Manchester, though, The 25-year-old is under contract until the end of the 2025-26 season, playing regularly this term when fit, and has opened up on his future.

“There’s been a lot of talk about this issue, but I’m happy in Barcelona," Araujo said, as translated by Football Espana. "In addition, we have to finish the season well because there are still challenges, also with Uruguay with the Copa America.”
Araujo linked up with Uruguay's squad for the March international break. He wasn't involved in the friendly against the Basque Country, though, with Matias Vecino netting in a 1-1 draw.
Marcelo Bielsa's team have been handed an inviting draw in the upcoming Copa America. Hosts the United States will be one of their group stage opponents, along with Panama and Bolivia.

"If I'm a player like Ronald who I think has every attribute to be one of the best defenders in the world, why are you going United?" Ferdinand said on his Vibe with Five show before the turn of the year.

"I'd be looking at Varane and going if he can go to Manchester United and get benched for a left-back, or for an old veteran like Jonny Evans an ex-player who has come back for his twilight years and someone who used to be captain who was left out for 18 months but is back in form now and is playing, I can't go there and risk my life and risk my career.
"If you look at it, what player has gone to Man United and got better? Varane has got worse, Casemiro has gone backwards now. You'd get good money for Bruno still, he's the only one.

"[Aaron] Wan-Bissaka you aren't getting £50million for, they aren't getting what they paid for [Diogo] Dalot. I could go through them all. [Alejandro] Garnacho has got value now, but I don't know who comes in? Would you get the same money for [Rasmus] Hojlund now? No! [Jadon] Sancho? No! I could keep going if you want. [Donny] Van de Beek?"

headline: Declan Rice makes feelings clear after Kobbie Mainoo handed England debut
body: Kobbie Mainoo only made his first Premier League start back in November but the teenager has now already earned an England cap after coming off the bench against Brazil
Declan Rice shared his love for Kobbie Mainoo after the Manchester United midfielder made his England debut against Brazil on Saturday.

Mainoo, 18, who has impressed during his breakthrough campaign at United, earned his first Three Lions call-up last week having initially being named in the Under 21 squad. After being named on the bench, the teenage sensation replaced Conor Gallagher and came on for the final 15 minutes at Wembley.

Despite playing for less than a quarter of the match, Mainoo didn't look out of place and showed the calmness, composure and technical ability he has at his disposal. The United youngster slotted in nicely alongside Rice in central midfield, with Phil Foden ahead of them in the No.10 role.

Reacting to his England debut in an Instagram post, Mainoo said: "Special feeling making my senior @England debut at Wembley and in front of my family. A moment I will never forget. Now we bounce back and refocus for Tuesday," followed by a love heart emoji.

Several of his England and United teammates were present in the comments section and Rice was among them to praise Mainoo. "Many more to come! Congrats bro," Rice said followed by a clapping emoji and a love heart.

United captain Bruno Fernandes added: "First of many," alongside a raising hands emoji. Harry Maguire said: "Deserved mate," while Luke Shaw commented: "What a player." Cole Palmer, James Maddison, Teden Mengi and Alejandro Garnacho also congratulated Mainoo.
Southgate explained the decision to bring on Mainoo, who was only bumped up to the senior side after a flurry of injuries in the camp. "Kobbie was a chance to dip his toes," the England boss said.
"We needed to refresh some of the team because we’ve got to manage their minutes a little bit, so that’s a strange situation when it’s a game of that size but that’s where we are."

"To get Kobbie on the pitch was a brilliant moment for him and his family. You saw a couple of turns and a couple of really composed moments that is a bit of an indication of what he might become," he added.

After making his first Premier League against Everton start in November, Mainoo has become an integral member of the United side. In fact, the teenager has started in 15 of their last 16 matches and scored his first top-flight goal during the 4-3 victory over Wolves last month.

Speaking after Mainoo netted a last-gasp winner at Molineux on February 1, Ten Hag said: "I think very quickly I saw him. I think last autumn I saw him for the first time and at that moment I thought he was playing a little bit too comfortable in the Under-21s, he should be much more dominant.
"We pushed him a lot by that side, by pushing him in training and you see he makes such good progress and he is almost progressing from game to game.
"And of course, it’s wonderful to see and I hope he stays calm like he is, as he did with his goal as well. He is determined, he is a good character and I hope he keeps going with this progress."

headline: Man Utd given clear response after setting out Mason Greenwood transfer demands
body: Mason Greenwood could leave Manchester United on a permanent deal this summer and Atletico Madrid are not fond of the Red Devils' reported asking price for the forward
Atletico Madrid have been left shocked with Manchester United asking for more than £50million for Mason Greenwood.

Greenwood, 22, has spent the current campaign on loan at Getafe and has impressed, plundering eight goals and providing five assists in 27 matches. His spell in La Liga comes after United completed an internal investigation after charges against the England forward of attempted rape, controlling and coercive behaviour, and assault were dropped by the Crown Prosecution Service in February of 2023.

Getafe are hoping to keep Greenwood on loan again for another season but United have decided they want a fee for the striker if they are going to part ways this summer. And it's understood Greenwood has received interested from a number of other clubs, including Atletico.

But according to Spanish outlet Mundo Deportivo, Diego Simeone's side are stunned by United's 'outrageous' asking price. They claim the Red Devils want £51.3m for Greenwood, which would represent their fourth-most expensive sale ever behind Cristiano Ronaldo, Romelu Lukaku and Angel di Maria.

Greenwood has not played United since January 2022 and Sir Jim Ratcliffe is yet to make a decision on whether to regenerate the academy graduate back into the first-team fold at Old Trafford or sell him. Ratcliffe said last month: "We will make a decision, correct.
"All I can do is talk about the principle of how we will approach decisions like that. Is he the right type of footballer, are we happy with if is he a good person or not?

"He's a Manchester United footballer, so we are in charge of football. So the answer is 'Yeah, we have to make decisions. It's quite clear we have to make a decision. There is no decision that's been made. He's on-loan obviously, but he's not the only one.

"We've got one or two footballers that we have to deal with and we have to make a decision on so we will do that. The process will be: understand the facts, not the hype. Then try and come to a fair decision on the basis of values, which is basically is he a good guy or not? Could he play sincerely for Manchester United well, would we be comfortable with it and would the fans be comfortable with it?"

Ratcliffe isn't the only one who has been discussing Greenwood, after England boss Gareth Southgate was asked about the talented forward. Greenwood has one Three Lions cap to his name, which came off the bench during their 1-0 win over Iceland in September 2020.
Southgate said: "I don't think it's something for pre-Euros. Allowing him to get his career going again abroad appears to have been a good move. But I have to say I have not tracked it closely."
Greenwood is contracted to United until the summer of 2025.

headline: What happened to the Man Utd duo Ian Wright named and shamed as being 'not good enough'
body: Ian Wright made his thoughts on Manchester United duo Harry Maguire and Victor Lindelof very clear back in September 2020 after a defeat by Crystal Palace and it appears the Red Devils have not heeded his warning
Ian Wright slammed Harry Maguire and Victor Lindelof as "not good enough" three years ago - but the pair remain at Manchester United.

The Arsenal icon tore into the duo following a disastrous display in a 3-1 defeat to Crystal Palace in September 2020. Speaking at the time, Wright said: "They've got to sort out that centre-half pairing, for me. It's not good enough at this level for Man United if they're challenging for stuff. Lindelof and Maguire, not good enough.
"The fact is, that is not good enough. At this level, with what Man United are supposedly meant to be trying to do, people are talking about Jadon Sancho coming, what's the point?
"You're going to get Jadon Sancho but still have two centre-halves who got absolutely roasted [against Palace] without actually trying too hard."

While Wright was clearly not a fan of the pair, they actually remain at Old Trafford three-and-a-half years later. Maguire remained a key player for the Red Devils throughout the 2020/21 season under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

He made 52 appearances for Man United in all competitions as they reached the Europa League final, only to lose out to Spanish side Villarreal. Maguire’s game time dropped the following campaign after the signing of Raphael Varane, while he only started eight Premier League games during Erik ten Hag's first season at the helm.
The ex-Leicester star did however help the Red Devils end their trophy drought as he lifted the Carabao Cup. Things took a turn during Ten Hag’s second campaign.

Maguire was stripped of the captaincy before the season had even started, while West Ham attempted to sign him. The Red Devils even went as far as accepting a £30m offer from the Hammers, but a deal with the defender could not be agreed.
He has since forced himself back into the reckoning at Old Trafford. To date, the 24-year-old has made 24 appearances and won the Premier League Player of the Month award for November.

Elsewhere, Lindelof hasn’t exactly met the heights expected of him since his big-money move from Benfica in 2017. He made 45 appearances the season of Wright’s criticism, with his game time in the Premier League dropping ever since.

The current campaign has actually represented an excellent opportunity for the Swede. With Varane and Lisandro Martinez struggling with injury issues this term, Ten Hag has regularly called upon Lindelof.
He was originally due to be out of contract this summer but an automatic one-year extension in his deal has been activated so it appears that he will stay at Old Trafford for the foreseeable future.

headline: Man Utd make final decision on Scott McTominay's future after change of heart
body: Scott McTominay has endured an impressive season at Manchester United and he is set to be rewarded with a new contract, despite Erik ten Hag's willingness to sell last summer
Manchester United have offered Scott McTominay a new long-term contract - less than 12 months after being deemed surplus to requirements at Old Trafford.

McTominay, 27, was subject to interest from West Ham last summer and was open to the idea of leaving United in search of regular first-team football. Boss Erik ten Hag had not started McTominay in each of their opening four Premier League matches and his future was looking in doubt.

However, the Scotland international has since performed a remarkable turnaround to become an integral member of the United squad. He has plunged nine goals and grabbed three assists in 34 appearances for the Red Devils this season and is their second top scorer behind striker Rasmus Hojlund.

Now, according to the Daily Star, United are set to hand McTominay a new deal as a reward for his uptick in form and performances this term. The midfielder has 15 months left to run on his current £60,000 per-week contract - and the club have an option to extend that by a further year.

There is no urgency for United to tie him down now, but co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe is keen to secure McTominay on a longer contract and give him a pay rise, too. The Red Devils are willing to double his salary to £120,000 per-week, which would limit or even stop transfer interest in the summer window.

Before McTominay made his 48th cap for Scotland in their 4-0 defeat against the Netherlands on Friday, he was named as their Player of the Year. That followed a quite stunning Euro 2024 qualifying campaign for the Lancaster-born midfielder, who scored seven goals in eight matches for the Tartan Army.

Speaking after winning the award, McTominay said: "Obviously, to win something like this, the Scotland men's Player of the Year, is amazing. We've had a good season, in terms of the results we've had and obviously getting to the Euros, and now we want to kick on and do well from here.
"There were a few [highlights]. I had the goal in Spain that was disallowed and it's probably my favourite ever goal I've not scored! So I'd probably say the other two goals against Spain.
"It was a historic night for us all, what we want more of them to come hopefully in the future, so we can kick on and show we are capable of beating teams as good as Spain."

headline: When Aaron Wan-Bissaka shocked the Man Utd squad - 'We talked about it in the dressing room'
body: A LOOK BACK: Manchester United have missed the defensive capabilities of Aaron Wan-Bissaka during his spells out injured, but that's not the only quality he can offer

Manchester United defender Aaron Wan-Bissaka is well-known for his defending ability, especially in one-on-one situations, but the right-back once showed his team-mates he can be handy in front of goal when he wants to be.

Wan-Bissaka, signed for £50m from Crystal Palace in 2019, arrived with that lofty reputation - one which many expected him to build on at Old Trafford. There have been moments at which that has been true, but there have also been injury worries - including the hamstring issue which sidelined him early this season and the separate muscular problem which struck in the new year.

The defender returned to action in the FA Cup quarter-final against Liverpool, playing 71 minutes of the dramatic extra-time victory. It was his first outing since mid-January, when he completed the full 90 against Spurs in the Premier League.

He has two assists to his name this term, but no goals, and has only scored twice in United colours. Both of those goals came in the 2020-21 season under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, with one in particular catching the eye of his colleagues.

United made a slow start to the 2020-21 campaign. A controversial late victory at Brighton - with a match-winning penalty awarded after the final whistle - was sandwiched by home defeats against Crystal Palace and Tottenham with an aggregate score of 2-9.

The pressure was mounting when United travelled to Newcastle for their fourth game of the season, and it grew further when a Luke Shaw own goal put the hosts in front. United levelled through Harry Maguire, but it was still 1-1 going into the final five minutes.

It was at this point that Solskjaer's team turned the screw. Three late goals followed, with Fernandes scoring the crucial second, but it was Wan-Bissaka's effort - latching onto a Marcus Rashford pass to blast high into Karl Darlow's net - which really caught the eye.
"[We were so happy] because we didn't know he can shoot!" fellow scorer Fernandes told MUTV at the time. "So it's difficult for us believing he can score because we never see him shooting.

"We were talking about it now in the dressing room and asking him because we all were thinking he wanted to cross and he makes a bad ball and scores. But I'm happy for him, he deserved the goal and we always ask this from him. Be more positive, be more in the box, try and improve because he has such good qualities.

Despite the goal, the Portuguese demanded more from his colleague. "Everyone knows about him being a defensive player and everything but he needs to show that he's more than a defensive player and I think he has the qualities to show that," he added.

By his own standards, Wan-Bissaka didn't have to wait too much longer for another goal. It came early on against Southampton in February 2021, when he ghosted in at the back post to score the first of nine unanswered goals for United.

He hasn't scored again since, though. Indeed, the next season was less enjoyable for the defender, who found minutes harder to come by, but in 2023 he opened up on how Erik ten Hag's arrival had helped him revive his career at Old Trafford.

"It can go both ways," he told The Mail. "You can just sit there and complain about it and not care, or you can actually try. I thought the best way was for me to try. It’s obviously never good. But I just had to deal with it. I had support around me, my family, telling me every day, 'Just keep working hard, have faith, your time will come'.

"So that helped me get through each day. I always have that faith in myself to get myself out of situations like that. I had my head screwed on and I was ready to do what it takes. Probably after January, I felt it I was in the right direction. I felt good about myself. I was happy. I just wanted to keep improving."

Back in January, United triggered an option to extend Wan-Bissaka's contract until the summer of 2025. Between now and then, he has a chance to show those displays of finishing ability three seasons ago were no fluke.

headline: What happened to forgotten Man Utd star tipped to be next Thomas Muller back in 2020
body: Manchester United signed Donny van Beek four years ago but the Dutchman has endured a horror spell at Old Trafford despite comparisons to Bayern Munich's Thomas Muller
Manchester United were told they had a player in the mould of Thomas Muller when they signed Donny van de Beek in 2020.

The Red Devils captured the Ajax playmaker for £40million and saw him score on his debut, albeit in a losing cause. Nevertheless it looked as if the Dutchman's form would quick translate from Amsterdam to Manchester, but that never proved to be the case.

Van de Beek would likely blame his failures at United on his coaches, who have continued to neglect him, issuing him with false promises and creating scenarios that aid him coming up short. The versatile star played as a striker for the exciting Ajax side that made the last four of the Champions League in 2019.

He was equally adept at playing in midfield, much like Muller, who has occupied almost every position in midfield and attack for Bayern during his career. Owen Hargreaves previously heaped praise on Van de Beek, and thought he could've been United's answer to the German, but instead he's now in his second loan spell away as he looks to find form and minutes.

Hargreaves told BT Sport back in 2020: "I think he's a really good player. He hasn't had the opportunity to show it. He could be like what Thomas Muller is for Bayern Munich - the style. Everybody tried to get Thomas Muller out of the team, but once he's in you can't get him out in terms of goals, assists, he's very unselfish, he can press the ball, he works in a midfield three, he can play as an 8 or a 10.

"[Van de Beek] is one of those... once he's in the team, Ole is going to find it hard to get him out.The problem you have is: You've got £100m Pogba, Bruno Fernandes... getting them all in one team with the front three they have is going to be a challenge for Ole."

The Dutchman ended up starting just four matches in his debut Premier League season - and when he did the spotlight was firmly on him. His fortunes hardly improved the following year but Solskjaer appeared to deflect any blame any from himself.

He said: "I manage a squad full of international footballers, competitive footballers who want to make a difference, want to play. They all want to be on the pitch, of course they do. I understand the frustration. Every player is keen to play. That's got to be built into energy and some determination for when you get on and then show me. That is not just Donny, that is all the players."

Van de Beek would be quick to say he needed opportunities to prove his worth and they continued to elude him. He sat on the bench for the Europa League final defeat and the status quo continued the following season.

He was in the matchday squad for the first 12 games of the season - but got just 61 minutes on the pitch. He came off the bench and scored in a defeat at Watford, which proved to be the last game of the Solskjaer era as results nosedived.

Van de Beek's fortunes failed to improve when Ralf Rangnick came in as interim boss and, at the first chance he got, the midfielder moved away on loan, joining Everton to aid their fight for survival. He started in seven of the nine games he was available for the Toffees, scoring once.

When he returned to Manchester that summer Erik ten Hag had been appointed as the new man in the Old Trafford dugout. It was under Ten Hag that Van de Beek played such an effective role at Ajax. Many felt that the stars had aligned for the Dutchman, but that wasn't the case.

He continued to be shunned by the manager, who challenged him to force his ay into the team: "It’s either he fights and proves himself in this environment or he goes, but for me, there is still a way for him, but it’s not going to be easy for him because the competition there is really strong."

Van de Beek though started just twice in the first half of the season before a knee ligament injury curtailed his season. If the Dutchman thought his minutes had been at a premium then this season presented a new low as he got just two minutes in the first 20 games.

That encouraged him to head out on loan once again and he now finds himself in Germany with Frankfurt. He's featured in six of the ten games since he joined the Bundesliga club, although he has been left out of their Europa League squad.

Upon leaving Manchester Van de Beek did offer a subtle hint at his frustration when his temporary exit was confirmed. "If you don't play as many games as you want, it's tough, but that's the past now. I'm here now and I'm positive," he said. Muller meanwhile is now 34 but has featured in 24 of Bayern's 26 Bundesliga games as he remains a stalwart.

headline: Man Utd news: New date confirmed for league clash as Bruno Fernandes drops new hint
body: Erik ten Hag faces a huge few weeks for his Manchester United side and will hope his squad members return to club duty unscathed following the international break
The international break is providing an opportunity for Erik ten Hag and his Manchester United squad to take stock of things ahead of the run-in.

United's final game before the intermission saw them secure a dramatic and much-needed victory over Liverpool to reach the semi-finals of the FA Cup. There's still plenty of work to do in the league, though, with a nine-point gap to fourth-placed Aston Villa.
Ten Hag's team do at least have a game in hand on Unai Emery's men, though. There's now a date in place for that fixture, as United prepare for the final 10 matches of the league season.
There's also news from captain Bruno Fernandes, one of the United stars currently away on international duty. Here are Mirror Football's latest lines from around Old Trafford.

Manchester United will now take on Sheffield United on April 24 at 8pm. The match was originally scheduled for last weekend but was postponed thanks to the Red Devils' continued involvement in the FA Cup.

It's one of a number of rearranged games confirmed by the Premier League, with others moved for TV. Three other games moved for the FA Cup quarter-finals will be televised - including the Merseyside Derby between Liverpool and Everton - but United's meeting with the Blades will not.

Erik ten Hag's team will play the relegation battlers just three days after meeting Coventry City in the FA Cup semi-finals. That match will kick off at 3.30pm, with the winner facing either Manchester City or Chelsea in the final.

Kobbie Mainoo is famous in his own right, but football fans are now learning the midfielder's brother has a claim to fame of his own. Jordan Mainoo-Hames appeared on Love Island in 2019, entering on day 14 and leaving on day 52.

United midfielder Mainoo has impressed for the club since returning from injury this season. The teenager was initially named in the England Under-21 squad for the March international break, only for Gareth Southgate to then add him to the senior squad.

England boss Gareth Southgate had initially indicated he wanted Mainoo to play more senior club minutes before earning a call-up, only to later bring him into the camp. "He's a good footballer - you can see that. And he's getting some fabulous experience with Manchester United at the moment. And he looks a really good character," the Three Lions boss said.

Manchester United captain Bruno Fernandes has hinted that his future could lie in a deeper midfield role. The Portuguese international tends to operate as an advanced midfielder for his club, even occasionally operating in a front three, but opened the door to an eventual change.

"In terms of passing, game organisation, defence, tactics. I have a little thought in my head that I'm going to end my career further back, because everyone who started there and went to No.10 ended up retreating on the field at the end," Fernandes told A Bola during the international break.

"It's a position I like, playing deeper, facing the game more. With the ball, it makes my game a lot easier because I have a broader view of the game and it is ideal for what we've talked about with the last pass, which can sometimes come from deeper on the pitch.
"The game with Everton was the one in which I created the most scoring opportunities, even though I was playing deeper and not playing as a No.10."

headline: Kylian Mbappe's transfer offers £86m opportunity to Man Utd, Liverpool and Arsenal
body: Kylian Mbappe is closing in on a mega-money switch to Real Madrid at the end of his Paris Saint-Germain contract and his move appears to have opened up a chance of another stunning transfer
Real Madrid have put a host of Premier League teams on red alert - with Brazilian winger Rodrygo potentially up for sale.

The Spanish side are set to add to their attacking options this summer with the addition of Kylian Mbappe. The Frenchman is move to Spain in the summer on a free transfer once his Paris Saint-Germain contract expires.
His arrival at the Santiago Bernabeu leaves Carlo Ancelotti’s squad looking slightly bloated. Their wage bill will also increase rapidly, with Mbappe set to put pen to paper on an eye-watering deal.
In order to address that, Real Madrid are reportedly willing to cash-in on Rodrygo. According to Spanish outlet Sport, they want to receive around €100million (£86m) for his services.
While they are open to a sale, they are not yet entertaining offers just yet. There is interest in the Premier League from Manchester United, Liverpool and Arsenal.
Indeed, Rodrygo’s future with Real Madrid looks slightly uncertain. He has been linked with an exit in the past but claimed he was happy in Spain.

Speaking last year, the 23-year-old said: "I didn't get any offer from Saudi League. I'm not interested about Premier League rumours. To be honest I'm only thinking about playing for Real Madrid, nothing else. I love Real Madrid. It's all perfect here."

The former Santos star has over four years left to run on his deal with Real Madrid. He has scored 13 goals in all competitions this season but Carlo Ancelotti was forced to leap to his defence earlier this year for a perceived lack of goal threat.

The Italian said: "I've been taught that if you tell someone 'think of all the animals except the cat, you think of the cat'. He's playing and contributing. I'll never talk to him about the goals he doesn't score, ever. The important thing is that he contributes, as he is doing.”

While Real Madrid have a decision to make over the future of Rodrygo, they are still yet to formally announce Mbappe’s arrival. The French striker remained tight-lipped on his future on international duty.
"I haven't announced anything yet because I have nothing to announce ... I am sorry I have nothing to tell you," he said, before adding: "I think it will all be sorted out before the Euros."

Elsewhere, PSG boss Luis Enrique was silent when asked about an exit for his star forward. He said: "Mbappe to Real Madrid? I don't know, no one knows. Only Kylian knows. When all parties involved decide to share the truth and their decisions, we will be there to listen."

headline: Man Utd draft nine-man shortlist of Gareth Southgate alternatives to replace Erik ten Hag
body: Manchester United’s new co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe was previously targeting Gareth Southgate as the Red Devils’ new boss but he also has a host of alternatives in mind
Manchester United have a 10-man shortlist to replace Erik ten Hag which includes Zinedine Zidane and Thomas Tuchel.

The Red Devils boss has been under growing pressure this term amid a disappointing second season at the helm. Sir Jim Ratcliffe could choose to make a change in the hotseat after becoming a minority shareholder.

England boss Gareth Southgate was at the forefront of his thinking but he has batted away the prospect of moving to Old Trafford. Speaking on Friday, he said: “I’m certainly not going to speak to anyone else, I never have, I’ve been eight years in the job and would never entertain speaking to anyone else while I’m in a job, so I don’t know if that answers your question.
“My focus is the European Championship. If we did a contract here before then everybody would be saying: ‘Why are you signing a contract before a Euros where you’ve got to prove yourself?’”

Southgate added: “There are two things from my point of view. Firstly, I am the England manager and I have got one job, basically, to try and deliver a European championship. Clearly, before that, two important games this week.

“And the second thing is Manchester United have a manager. I think it is always completely disrespectful when there is any speculation about a manager who is in place. I am president of the LMA so I don’t have any time for that sort of thing.”
While Southgate’s admission might be a disappointment, Ratcliffe has a number of back-up plans. According to ESPN, up to 10 managers - including the England boss - are under consideration.

Alternative options include former Chelsea bosses Graham Potter and Thomas Tuchel - with the latter set to leave Bayern Munich at the end of the season. Elsewhere, a host of managers currently in jobs could emerge as options.
Brentford’s Thomas Frank and Roberto De Zerbi of Brighton could potentially be approached should Ratcliffe settle on a change. The options do not end there.

The Australian has impressed during his time with Tottenham since his summer move from Celtic but the North Londoners are unlikely to let him go easily. While the Red Devils consider their options, they might need trigger talks with Ten Hag.
The Dutchman has a year-and-a-half remaining on his contract at Old Trafford. It has been claimed that it could cost around £14m to dismiss him and his staff.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo reveals Man Utd dressing room nickname thanks to his famous brother
body: Manchester United star Kobbie Mainoo has revealed what his nickname is back at Old Trafford ahead of his potential England debut against Brazil on Saturday night
Manchester United's teenage sensation Kobbie Mainoo has revealed his nickname in the Red Devils dressing room - and it's a reference to his famous family member.

The 18-year-old has been one of the shining lights for the Red Devils this term in what has been an otherwise underwhelming campaign and as a result, has earned his first senior England call-up. It was while away on international duty that Mainoo explained what some of his United colleagues call him back in Manchester.

Speaking in his England's 'First Impressions' interview, Mainoo shed light on the fact that his team-mates at club level affectionately call him 'Love Island', as a nod to the fact his brother Jordan Mainoo-Hames featured on the reality show back in 2019.

"My brother was on it," the United midfield ace explained. "I'm close to him. You know what, going back to another question - my nickname. The kit man at United always called me 'Love Island'. [He's been doing so] since I was like 16."
Keen to point out that Mainoo is not one to turn on the charm like Love Island viewers saw his brother do, the Red Devils star added: "No, it's not even that. They're just jokers."

Mainoo's England call-up marks the next step in what has been a meteoric rise to first-team football for both club and country. Keen to reach the next level, the 18-year-old admitted he has his sights set on being named in Gareth Southgate's squad for Euro 2024 in the summer.

"I think that’s the end goal for the season, to get into that squad," Mainoo revealed, after his first training session with England at senior level. "Obviously I’ve got to focus on club football in the meantime, and hopefully that’ll figure itself out.
“It’s been a pretty mad couple of days, Sunday ­obviously was a great game and a great win. Then to get called up to the Under-21s, ­obviously I was excited to come.
"Then getting down here and realising that I was with the first team was amazing. I was shocked and happy and it’s been a whirlwind of emotions."

England welcome Brazil to Wembley on Saturday night, before meeting Belgium on Tuesday at the same venue. Just how many minutes Mainoo will receive remains to be seen, but he is thought incredibly highly of by Three Lions boss Southgate.
